Authors:
Michaela M. Hofmann, Constantin M. Zohner, Susanne S
Renner
Title:
Narrow habitat breath and late-summer emergence increase
extinction vulnerability in Central European bees
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B 286
Keywords:
Climate warming | Bee life-history traits | Comparative
phylogenetic methods | Central Europe | Red List | Extinction
vulnerability
Abstract:
Evaluating the relative roles of intrinsic and extrinsic
traits in predisposing species to local extinction is important for
targeting conservation efforts. Among the species of greatest
conservation concern in the temperate zone are bees, which along with
butterflies are also the most intensely monitored insects. Bees are most
species-rich in Mediterranean-type climates with short winters, warm
springs, and dry summers. In Central Europe, climate warming is
therefore expected to benefit bees, while pesticides and the loss of
habitats and plant diversity should constitute threats. We here use
phylogenetically-informed hierarchical Bayesian models to analyze the
simultaneous effects of intrinsic and extrinsic traits affecting bee
populations, including habitat breadth, pollen specialization, body
size, nesting sites, mean flight time, duration of flight activity, and
others. Because German bees have been monitored for conservation Red
Lists for 40+ years, each factors predictive power can be tested against
documented population trends. Surprisingly, late-summer emergence was
among the strongest predictors of vulnerability, with a statistical
model that includes interactions among narrow habitat preference, short
flight time, and late-summer emergence correctly predicting the
vulnerability status of 85% of the species. Conversely, spring emergence
and occurrence in urban areas or along hedgerows reduces vulnerability,
pointing to the antagonistic effects of climate warming (benefitting
spring-active bees) and intensive agriculture (harming summer-active
bees), with the combination of these factors currently shifting Germanys
bee diversity towards warm-adapted, spring-flying, city-dwelling
species.
